A PASTORAL.</br>As late I had trip'd o'er the green,</br>And stray'd thro' the meadows new mow'd,</br>Believe me I never had seen,</br>Such richness by nature bestow'd.
The gold locks of Ceres gay wav'd,</br>And rewarded the husbandman's toil,</br>Each sickle's production when sheav'd,</br>Enraptur'd they bore off the spoil.
Whilst pleasure smil'd sweet on their brow,</br>And beam'd with sereneness divine,</br>I wish'd, but I cou'd not tell how,</br>To alter their station for mine.
For O!  never more shall I know,</br>That spring of perfection so chaste,</br>Call'd bliss; but the weight of keen woe,</br>Evermore I am doomed to taste.
Ah!  sure my Eliza is flown!</br>That form so angelic and fair,</br>Is fled, and left Strephon alone,</br>In absence sigh and despair.
Each power to please and to gain,</br>Was by the dear cherub possest,</br>Which ev'ry nymph of the plain,</br>Her perfections superior confest.
Not the hue of a dew-spangled rose,</br>When opening before the fresh day,</br>Such blushes as here could disclose,</br>Nor such sweets to my lips cou'd convey.
The mildness of new infant spring,</br>In its vernal soft beauties array'd,</br>Ne'er such raptures from nature could bring,</br>As the smiles my Eliza display'd.
The swift-twinkling orbs of the night,</br>Whose lustres both please and surprize,</br>Dispens'd not a splendor so bright,</br>As the rays of her love-sparkling eyes.
Had their radiance less fire express'd</br>I then might have view'd without pain,</br>But soon did they wound my fond breast,</br>And its peace I can never regain.
For fate, cruel fate, not long since,</br>Had stol'n the fair nymph far away,</br>From a constant fond heart bore her hence,</br>And darken'd, my hopes with dismay.
Say then, to what shade shall I run,</br>What desertless path shall pursue?</br>Since Eliza for ever is gone,</br>I must bid to the world an adieu.
Yes, quick to the covert I'll fly,</br>Where my charmer and I often stray'd,</br>Tho' there I no more shall descry,</br>Those blisses with her it convey'd.
No more will its warbling sweet train,</br>Bear sympathy with our fond verse,</br>Nor seek in their wonted soft strain,</br>Her softer sweet notes to rehearse.
Alone I shall enter its bow'r,</br>Alone to the grove I shall hie,</br>Alone there I'll languish each hour,</br>There alone for Eliza I'll die.
</br>PASTORAL II.</br>Behold the sweet banks of the grove,</br>Whose flowrets enamell'd the green;</br>Far away with Eliza thy rove,</br>And their beauties no longer are seen.
The clear gliding streams that did flow,</br>In numbers harmonious along,</br>No more their enchantments bestow,</br>Or gently keep pace with the song.
All blasted the woodbines appear,</br>Their verdures are faded away,</br>And no more shall the jessamine here,</br>Its wide-spreading branches display.
While the swelling round tears quickly fall,</br>As his woes no kind solace cou'd find,</br>Reflection, with pain to recall,</br>By a willow young Strephon reclin'd.
As trembles the note of the lyre,</br>When touch'd it neglectedly strung,</br>In plaintive weak murmurs expire,</br>The faultering notes from his tongue.
To calm his rack'd bosom he try'd,</br>In sorrow, essay'd oft in vain,</br>Alternate, dull echo reply'd,</br>And return'd his sad wail back again.
O ye zephyrs, who sportively play,</br>Your wantons give o'er, and draw nigh,</br>On swift, fleeting pinions convey</br>To my charmer each tender breath'd sigh.
Then fly nimbly, and tell the dear maid,</br>That for ever I've bade her adieu:</br>Strephon's love, it will ne'er be betray'd,</br>But still will prove constant and true.
O ye songsters, who fill'd the wide air,</br>As you warbled your notes from each spray,</br>When hither I led my fond fair,</br>Say, say, whither now do you stray?
O forsake not your wonted retreat,</br>Each shade it invokes your return;</br>When you chaunted, my bliss was compleat,</br>Now sympathize with me, and mourn.
But Eliza, 'twas she cou'd inspire,</br>With raptures your loud swelling song;</br>For her, you assembled the choir,</br>And hail'd her approaches along.
Be ye heedful then whither you fly,</br>Return, and pray cease for to rove,</br>If you catch but a glance of her eye,</br>Farewell to the grot and the grove.
And ye swains who oft trip o'er the dew,</br>Of her artless attractions beware,</br>If you shou'd the dear Sylvan pursue,</br>No hopes, can you find, but despair.
For the fair one, where-ever she goes,</br>All nature enflames with desire,</br>And, as sure will she blast the repose,</br>Of the youth, who but dares to admire.
</br>PASTORAL III.</br>Hark!  hark!  to the plaintiff that roams</br>Amidst the entwining deep shade;</br>'Tis Philomel — hither she comes;</br>'Twas her plaints to the breeze she convey'd.
See!  see!  her wide wing she extends</br>On quivering pinion, to fly,</br>By the slope of my willow descends,</br>And doleful reanswers each sigh.
As speeds the fleet moments that bear</br>Off the short earthly bliss we enjoy;</br>As swift as the flash rends the air,</br>Or the tempests fierce rage can destroy:
So flew the drear vision amain,</br>Whilst a ray of sublimity stole</br>From my woeing companion, whose strain</br>Soon reanimated the whole.
Attend, O my Strephon, she cried,</br>Whilst her form Seraphic, express'd</br>All Heaven — for, loe, by my side</br>The genius of hope stood confest.
Assuage thy wild fury dear swain,</br>And seek, as your wail you give o'er,</br>Your once enjoy'd peace to regain,</br>And calm reason peace shall restore.
Tho' your violets and roses that bloom'd,</br>Are faded and sunk to decay;</br>Think not that they less are perfum'd,</br>Since Eliza is gone far away.
Tho' the smiles that the charmer may wear,</br>With their tints so resplendently shine,</br>Yet, ne'er shall the plants of my care,</br>By her absence their odours resign.
Speed swiftly unto the blithe plain,</br>Where pleasures await the glad way,</br>'Tis then that your flowrets shall deign</br>Their long o'ercast bloom to display.
Go, welcome the young rising spring,</br>Attend the mild sport of the fields;</br>Taste the raptures calm nature can bring,</br>And her rural simplicity yields.
Then, for thee shall the tender plants blow,</br>Spread their opening foliage apace,</br>And the light tranquil smile on the brow,</br>The years youngest blossoms shall grace.
No never, celestial, I cried,</br>Can I my sad sorrows forgoe:</br>The effort, too dearly I've tried,</br>And life can no solace bestow.
For think not, O genius divine,</br>Tho' I'd sport with the festive gay trains,</br>My woes I could ever resign,</br>Whilst breath in my bosom remains.
Since fortune denies for to bless</br>My hopes with th' angelical fair;</br>Yet still, she this heart shall possess;</br>This heart, 'tis she only, shall share.
But if to yon circlet I bound,</br>Where sylvan and wood nymph do dwell,</br>My plaints o'er the plains shall resound,</br>—O ye pensive recesses — Farewell.

</br>PASTORAL IV.</br>Where the fountains soft murmuring flow,</br>The fragrance fresh breathes from the thorn;</br>Where the hill tops are shaded with snow,</br>Whilst sweet verdures the vallies adorn.
The opening landscape new deck'd,</br>Spreads its roseate mantle along,</br>And the smooth gliding stream can reflect</br>The sports of the festival throng.
Beside the embowering dale</br>My humble retirement lies;</br>And the flocks that o'erspread yonder vale,</br>Beyond its contentment I prize.
There I've planted the red blushing vine;</br>I have set me a slip from the rose;</br>And the May-blossom'd branches entwine</br>My younglings domain to inclose.
Not a hue o'er the mead can be found</br>But the vest of my villa contains;</br>My arbours melifluous resound,</br>And ring with the woodlark's loud strains.
For now the bleak season ne'er dares</br>To invade or disrobe the gay green;</br>And the longer its vista it wears,</br>More splendid appears the gay scene.
When the grey smiling mattin awakes,</br>To illume the dark gloom of the spheres,</br>The fond bird his young nestling forsakes,</br>And his shrill salutation prepares.
At the wonted approach of the morn</br>He mounts and he hails the glad skies,</br>Whilst confusion of notes from each thorn</br>The blissful retreats harmonize.
Light ting'd with the languid pale red,</br>The wide space of heaven appears,</br>Till Phoebus's bright flaming head,</br>O'er the golden capt mountain he rears.
His genial refreshing faint beams,</br>The clear trickling dew-drops disclose,</br>Ensilvers the serpentine streams,</br>And awakes the dull swain from repose.
Then my lambkins with innocent bleat,</br>O'er the lawn how they sportively run,</br>And with their fond pleasures elate,</br>They wantonly frisk in the sun.
Here my lonely retire it lies,</br>Tho' no longer impatient I mourn,</br>Since fate, cruel fate it denies—</br>Hapless thought! — my Eliza's return.
Yet my breast its repose can regain;</br>For peace, sweet enchantress!  bestows</br>A balm to assuage ev'ry pain,</br>And to ease the fierce rage of my woes.
Tho' the simple led vigil no more</br>Wakes my soul to its festal alarms,</br>My grotts and my white fleecy store</br>Can await me with gentler charms.
But still shall I waft with a sigh</br>O'er the green, my Eliza's dear name,</br>And the beauties that beam'd from her eye,</br>To the wide spreading valleys proclaim.</br>
